Blog Section

Tip Calculator

Posted by Jonathan on Jan 02 2024

The takeaway task for session 9. Intro to JS - Programming Concepts. This task introduces the use of JavaScript to add dynamic interactions with web pages. I initially created a Script tag into my index.html page and initiated variables to take the value of the bill via a prompt and calculate the value of the tip from a fixed percentage of 25% using the document.write method to output the total bill. I checked using the typeof operator that I was dealing with numbers at all times and utilised the toFixed method to round the output as per the task instructions. As I had a number of lines of code in my script tag, I moved the JavaScript to a separate file and linked to this from the html head. Unfortunately, I experienced problems with document.write in a separate JS file within VSCode, with the browser console throwing errors. I moved my code to CodePen and did not experience this issue there. I now made further changes to the code, changing the input method to a input field within the webpage with a submit button initiating a JS function to calculate the tip from the input bill value. Once working, I transferred the code back to VSCode and did not experience any further issues with document.write method, all seemed to be working as expected.

Intro to JS - Functions and Control Flow

Posted by Jonathan on Jan 10 2024

In this session learners were taught about how to write a function in Javascript. The learners also have to call the function to make it run. They were introduced to control flow and how to use logic inside of a function to return an output.

Task 1 - Write a function that outputs a sentence. Then invoke/use that function.
function sentence() { console.log('This is a sentence.') }
sentence();
Task 2 - Write a simple program to combine a first name and a last name inside a function. Then update the function to accept a first and last name as arguments.
function name(first, last) { console.log("Full Name: " + first + " " + last); }
name('Jim', 'Argument');
Task 3 - Add a return statement to your 'name' function. Use that function to set the value of a variable.
function name(first, last) { return "Full Name: " + first + " " + last; } let fullName = name('Jim', 'Return')
console.log(fullName);
Task 3 function as Arrow function
const name = (first, last) => "Full Name: " + first + " " + last;
console.log(name('Jim', 'Arrow'));
task 4.1 - Make a variable called "temperature". Write some code that tells you to put on a coat if it is less than 50.
let temperature = 49; if (temperature < 50) { console.log("Put on a coat") }
Task 4.2 - If it's less than 50 degrees, “wear a coat.” If it's less than 30 degrees, “wear a coat and a hat.” If it's less than 0 degrees, “stay inside.” Otherwise, “just pants and vest is fine.”
let temperature = 60; if (temperature < 0) { console.log("Stay inside.");
} else if (temperature < 30) { console.log("Wear a coat and a hat.");
} else if (temperature < 50) { console.log("Wear a coat.");
} else { console.log("Just pants and vest is fine.") }
Task 4.3 - Add a logical operator to your ‘Shall I wear a coat?’ program
let temperature = 25; let hat = true; if (temperature < 0) { console.log("Stay inside.");
} else if (temperature < 30 && hat) { console.log("Wear a coat and a hat.");
} else if (temperature < 50) { console.log("Wear a coat.");
} else { console.log("Just pants and vest is fine.") }

Practicals - Intro to JS - Functions and Control Flow - Tasks

Posted by Jonathan on Jan 17 2024

In this session learners completed practical tasks set to help them further understand the previous 2 sessions in 'Intro to JS - Programming Concept' and 'Intro to JS - Functions and Control Flow'.

Task 1 - Create a function that is able to return a percentage of a number. For example you want to know what 30% of 135 is.

  1. Create a function named percentageCalculator
  2. Add 2 arguments for “number” and “percentage”
  3. Do the maths required to work out a percentage with the arguments
  4. Return the result of the maths
  5. Console.log the returned value
function percentageCalculator (number, percentage) {
return number * percentage / 100;
}

console.log(percentageCalculator(135, 30));

/* Arrow function */
percentageCalculator = (number, percentage) => number * percentage / 100;

console.log(percentageCalculator(135, 30));

/* Using variables */
const number = 135
const percentage = 30

percentageCalculator = (number, percentage) => number * percentage / 100;

console.log(percentageCalculator(number, percentage));

/* Make dynamic by UI '+ ensures that string from UI is a number' */
const number = +prompt('What number')
const percentage = +prompt('what Percentage')

percentageCalculator = (number, percentage) => number * percentage / 100;

const result = percentageCalculator(number, percentage);

alert(`${percentage}% of ${number} is ${result}` )
Task 2 - Customers can order 3 types of drink in 3 sizes. Cola, Lemonade and Orangeade Small, Medium and Large The button they press have the values “cola”,”lemon”,”orange” Create a function that will return the message “You have ordered a {size} of {softDrinkLabel}

  1. Create a function named drinkOrder
  2. Add 2 arguments for “size” and “buttonName”
  3. Use a switch statement to determine where the functional code needs to be written
  4. Create a message in each case statement to be returned.
  5. Console.log the returned message.
  • Additional look at arrays - make dynamic
let buttonName = 'orange'
let size = 'Small'

function drinkOrder (buttonName, size) {
switch (buttonName) {
case 'cola':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Cola`
case 'lemon':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Lemonade`
case 'orange':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Orangeade`
}
}
console.log(drinkOrder(buttonName, size))

/* Make dynamic by UI */
const arrSize = ["Small","Medium","Large"];
const arrButtonName = ["cola","lemon","orange"]

/* Ensure drink size entry capitalised */
function titleCase(str) {
var splitStr = str.toLowerCase().split(' ');
for (var i = 0; i < splitStr.length; i++) {
splitStr[i] = splitStr[i].charAt(0).toUpperCase() + splitStr[i].substring(1);
}
return splitStr.join(' ');
}

let buttonName
let size

/* Prompt for drink type until correct entry */
do{
/* Ensure buttonName is lowercase */
buttonName = prompt('What type of drink: cola, lemon, orange').toLowerCase()
} while (arrButtonName.indexOf(buttonName) === -1);

/* Prompt for drink size until correct entry */
do{
size = titleCase(prompt('What size of drink: Small, Medium and Large'))
} while (arrSize.indexOf(size) === -1);

function drinkOrder (size, buttonName) {
switch (buttonName) {
case 'cola':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Cola`
case 'lemon':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Lemonade`
case 'orange':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Orangeade`
}
}
console.log(drinkOrder(size, buttonName))
Task 3 - We need to create a function capable of using the addition, subtraction, multiply, divider or modulus operator on 2 numbers provided.
let number1 = 7
let number2 = 5
let operator = '%'

function calculator (number1, number2, operator) {
switch (operator) {
case '+':
return number1 + number2
// break; don't need as return breaks out
case '-':
return number1 - number2
case '*':
return number1 * number2
case '/':
return number1 / number2
case '%':
return number1 % number2
}
}

let value = calculator(number1, number2, operator)

console.log(`${number1} ${operator} ${number2} = ${value}`)

/* Make dynamic by UI */
/* Extra work - Think how you could add validation to this script */
const arrOperator = ["+","-","*","/","%"];

/* Prompt for input until a number is entered */
function validate (argument) {
let number
do{
number = Number(prompt(`Enter ${argument}`))
} while (!(!Number.isNaN(number)));
return number
}

let number1 = validate("number1")
let operator

/* Prompt for input until a correct operator is entered */
do{
operator = prompt('Enter operator: +, -, *, /, %')
} while (arrOperator.indexOf(operator) === -1);

let number2 = validate("number2")

function calculator (number1, number2, operator) {
switch (operator) {
case '+':
return number1 + number2
// break; don't need as return breaks out
case '-':
return number1 - number2
case '*':
return number1 * number2
case '/':
return number1 / number2
case '%':
return number1 % number2
}
}

let value = calculator(number1, number2, operator)

console.log(`${number1} ${operator} ${number2} = ${value}`)

Pseudocode & Comments - Tasks

Posted by Jonathan on Feb 06 2024

In this session learners were be introduced to the concept of Pseudocode. The learners were also taught about the importance of comments and how to write comments in HTML, CSS and JS.

Task 1
Add comments to one of your past JS tasks from a previous lesson
# Problem
# Intro to JS Practicals - Tasks - Task 1 - Create a function that is able to return a percentage of a number. For example you want to know what 30% of 135 is.
  1. Create a function named percentageCalculator
  2. Add 2 arguments for “number” and “percentage”
  3. Do the maths required to work out a percentage with the arguments 4. Return the result of the maths 5. Console.log the returned value

# Solution
- Going to need a FUNCTION, which I will call percentageCalculator
- pass arguments to the Function of a given percentage (e.g. 30) and a given number (e.g. 135)
- Calculate the percentage
- divide the given percentage by 100
- multiple the given number by the calculate percentage
- return the calculation
- Call the function
- Output the returned percentage calculation to the console
Task 2
Produce a pseudocode response to one or more of the following challenges. As comments. # Problem
# FixStart - Create a function called fixStart. It should take a single argument, a string, and return a version where all occurrences of its first character have been replaced with ‘*****’, except for the first character itself. You can assume that the string is at least one character long. For example:
fixStart('babble'): 'ba**le'
fixStart('turtle'): 'tur*le'

# Solution
- Create a FUNCTION called fixStart.
- need to iterate over the length of the string as an array
- make comparison of each item in the string array to the first item
- if it matches then replace the array item with '*'
- if it does not match then leave the item as is
- console log out the string

Intro to JS - Loops, Arrays & Objects - Tasks

Posted by Jonathan on Jan 30 2024

In this session learners had loops explained to them. Learners were also introduced to 2 data types in detail (arrays & objects). Some simple tasks were worked through to demonstrate when they will be used and how.

Task 1 - Write a loop that outputs the 7 times table, from 7 x 1 = 7 to 7 x 12 = 84
for ( let i = 1; i <= 12; i++) {
console.log(`\n -------- \nThe ${i} times table \n`)
for ( let j = 1; j <=12; j++) {
console.log(`${i} x ${j} = ${i * j}`)
}
}
Task 2
  1. Create an array of your favourite foods.
  2. Print some of them to the screen
const foods = ['Fish & Chips', 'Pizza', 'Chicken Tikka Masala']
console.log(foods[0]);
console.log(foods[2]);
Task 3 - Use a for loop to print a list of all your favourite foods
/*for loop with a counter */
const foods = ['Fish & Chips', 'Pizza', 'Chicken Tikka Masala']
for (let i = 0; i < foods.length; i++) {
console.log(foods[i])
}

/* for...of syntax */
const foods = ['Fish & Chips', 'Pizza', 'Chicken Tikka Masala']
for (const food of foods) {
console.log(food)
}
Task 4 - Create an object to hold information on your favourite recipe. Then display the properties on screen.
Bonus Points: Create a loop to list all the ingredients and directions.
const recipe = {
title: 'Hot Chocolate Fudge',
servings: 4,
ingredients: [
'Chocolate Chips',
'Heavy Cream',
'Condensed Milk',
'Vanilla Extract',
'White Chocolate Chips',
'Miniature Marshmallows'],
directions: [
'Line an 8-inch-square baking pan with wax paper or foil, and coat with non-stick spray.',
'In a microwave-safe bowl, combine the dark chocolate chips, heavy cream and half of the sweetened condensed milk. Microwave the dark chocolate mixture in 20-second intervals, stirring in between each interval, until the chocolate is melted.', 'Add the vanilla extract to the dark chocolate mixture and stir well until smooth.',
'Transfer the dark chocolate mixture into the prepared pan and spread into an even layer.',
'In a separate bowl, combine the white chocolate chips with the remaining half of the sweetened condensed milk. Microwave the white chocolate mixture in 20-second intervals, stirring in between each interval, until the chocolate is melted.',
'Evenly spread the white chocolate mixture on top of dark chocolate layer.',
'Top the chocolate layers with the Mallow Bits or miniature marshmallows, and gently press them down.',
'Refrigerate for 4 hours, or until set.',
'Remove the fudge and wax paper from the pan. Carefully peel all of the wax paper from the fudge.',
'Cut the fudge into bite-sized pieces and serve.']
};

/* display the properties on screen. */
console.log(recipe.title);
console.log(recipe.servings);
console.log(recipe.ingredients);
console.log(recipe.directions);

/* Bonus Points: Create a loop to list all the ingredients and directions. */
console.log('\nIngredients:');
for (const ingredients of recipe.ingredients) {
console.log(ingredients);
}
console.log('\nDirections:');
for (const directions of recipe.directions) {
console.log(directions);
}
Task 5 - Add a function called letsCook. Have it say: "I'm hungry! Let's cook..." with the name of your recipe title. Call your new method.
/* Using Task 4 Recipe Object */
function letscook(recipe) {
console.log(`I'm hungry! Let's cook '${recipe.title}'`)
}
letscook(recipe);

Loops, Arrays & Objects Practical - Tasks

Posted by Jonathan on Feb 04 2024

Task 1 - Shopping Cart
We are going to be using an array of objects provided as a simple shopping cart example.
We need to work out the total cost of the items in the shopping cart.

Part 1
  1. Create a function that takes 1 argument (the array)
  2. Create a variable inside the function called “totalPrice”
  3. Loop through each item in the array and add the value of the item to the total price, remember to account for the quantity.
  4. Return the totalPrice Variable
  5. Console.log the returned value
var shoppingCart=[{name:"loaf of bread",type:"food",quantity:1,price:.85},{name:"multipack beans",type:"food",quantity:1,price:1},{name:"mushrooms",type:"food",quantity:10,price:.1},{name:"can of beer",type:"alcohol",quantity:4,price:1.1},{name:"prosecco",type:"alcohol",quantity:1,price:8.99},{name:"steak",type:"food",quantity:2,price:3.99},{name:"blue cheese",type:"food",quantity:1,price:2.99},{name:"candles",type:"home",quantity:3,price:1.99},{name:"cheesecake",type:"food",quantity:1,price:4.99},{name:"onions",type:"food",quantity:3,price:.4}];

function price(shoppingCart) {
let totalPrice = 0;
for (const item of shoppingCart) {
totalPrice = totalPrice + (item.price * item.quantity);
}
return totalPrice
}
Part 2
  1. Create a function that takes 1 argument (the array)
  2. Create a variable inside the function called “totalPrice”
  3. Loop through each item in the array and add the value of the item to the total price, remember to account for the quantity.
  4. If the item has a type of “food” the total price is 20% less
  5. Return the totalPrice Variable
const foodDiscount = 0.8;

function getTotal(cart) {
let totalprice = 0;

for (const item of cart) {
if (item.type == "food") {
let itemSubtotal = item.price * item.quantity * foodDiscount;
totalprice += itemSubtotal;
} else {
let itemSubtotal = item.price * item.quantity;
totalprice += itemSubtotal;
}
}
return totalprice;
}

console.log(getTotal(shoppingCart));
Part 3
  1. Add 2 extra arguments to the function for “discountAmount” and “type”
  2. Replace the logic that takes off 20% for object.type == “food” for object.type == type and allow the 20% to be the {discountAmount}%
  3. Create logic so that if type == “any” all products have a discount applied
const foodDiscount = 0.8;

function getTotal(cart, discountAmount, type) {
let totalprice = 0;

for (const item of cart) {
let itemSubtotal = item.price * item.quantity;

if (item.type == type || type == "any") {
itemSubtotal = itemSubtotal * discountAmount;
}

totalprice += itemSubtotal;
}
return totalprice;
}

console.log(getTotal(shoppingCart, foodDiscount, "food"));
Part 4
We are going to be using an array of objects provided as a simple shopping cart example.
We need to be able to work out which items cost between 2 price points. So for example, we need the cart to be returned by which products cost more than £2 but less than £5.
  1. Create a function that has 3 arguments “cart”, “lowPrice” and “highPrice”
  2. Create an empty array called arrItems at the start of the function.
  3. Loop through each item of the array
  4. If the price value is higher than or equal to the lowPrice and lower than or equal to the highPrice push to arrItems
function priceBetween(cart, lowPrice, highPrice) {
var arrItems=[]
for (const item of cart) {
if (item.price >= lowPrice && item.price <= highPrice) {
arrItems.push(item)
}
}
return arrItems;
}

console.log(priceBetween(shoppingCart, 2, 5))
Part 5
  1. Add an additional argument to the function “quantity” this is going to be a boolean
  2. If quantity == true then account for the total price with the quantity included as being between lowPrice and highPrice
function price(cart) {
let totalPrice = 0;
for (const item of cart) {
totalPrice = totalPrice + (item.price * item.quantity);
}
return totalPrice
}

function priceBetween(cart, lowPrice, highPrice, quantity) {
var arrItems=[]
for (const item of cart) {
if (item.price >= lowPrice && item.price <= highPrice) {
arrItems.push(item)
}
}
if(quantity){
return(price(arrItems))
} else {
return arrItems;
}
}

console.log(priceBetween(shoppingCart, 2, 5, false))
Additional Tasks
We are going to be creating a function that is able to take all of the values of an array and return the average.
Part 1
The function will be able to return the mode, median or mean of the numbers.
  1. Create an array of random numbers
  2. Create a function that takes 1 argument (the array) which can work out the mean of the numbers provided
  3. Create a function which can work out the mode of the numbers provided
  4. Create a function which can work out the median of the numbers provided
let numbers = [5, 5, 1, 2, 1, 1];

function mean (numbers) {
let total = 0;
for (const number of numbers) {
total = total + number;
}
total = total / numbers.length;
return total;
}

function mode (numbers) {
const modeCount = {};
for (const number of numbers) {
if(modeCount[number] === undefined) {
modeCount[number] = 1;
} else {
modeCount[number] += 1;
}
}

let currentHighestCount = 0;
let currentHighestNumber;

for (const entry of Object.entries(modeCount)) {
const number = entry[0];
const count = entry[1];
if(count > currentHighestCount) {
currentHighestCount = count;
currentHighestNumber = number;
}
}
return currentHighestNumber
}

function median (numbers) {
numbers.sort(function (a, b) {
return a - b;
});
const middleNumberPosition = Math.round(numbers.length /2) - 1;

return numbers[middleNumberPosition];
}

console.log(mode(numbers));
Part 2
  1. Create a new function which takes 2 arguments (the array and a type variable).
  2. Create a switch statement which has the cases ‘mode’, ‘median’ and ‘mean’
  3. Copy and paste the functionality from your 3 previous functions into the case statement
  4. Return the required number based on the arguments passed
let numbers = [5, 5, 1, 2, 1, 1];

function meanMedianMode(numbers, type) {
var text;

switch(type) {
case "mean":
let total = 0;
for (const number of numbers) {
total = total + number;
}
total = total / numbers.length;
return total;
case "mode":
const modeCount = {};
for (const number of numbers) {
if(modeCount[number] === undefined) {
modeCount[number] = 1;
} else {
modeCount[number] += 1;
}
}
let currentHighestCount = 0;
let currentHighestNumber;
for (const entry of Object.entries(modeCount)) {
const number = entry[0];
const count = entry[1];
if(count > currentHighestCount) {
currentHighestCount = count;
currentHighestNumber = number;
}
}
return currentHighestNumber
case "median":
numbers.sort(function (a, b) {
return a - b;
});
const middleNumberPosition = Math.round(numbers.length /2) - 1;
return numbers[middleNumberPosition];
default:
text = "I have never heard of that Average...";
return text;
}
}

console.log(meanMedianMode(numbers, "mean"));

Intro to JS - Intro to the DOM - Lesson Tasks

Posted by Jonathan on Feb 14 2024

Learners were introduced to the DOM (Document Object Model). They were shown how to make javascript bring a page to life by reacting to events. The learners were shown how to trigger function calls using on page events.

Task 1
  1. Go to the codepen.
  2. Look through the HTML first.
  3. Then try to update the JS so it sets the variables from the DOM.
// Modify the code below to set the variables appropriately.

// Get the form by ID from the forms collection.
const form = document.getElementById('todo');
// Get the todo pane (the 'ul' element).
const todoPane = document.getElementById('todo-pane');
// Get the text input for the title.
const titleInput = document.getElementById('title');
// Get the priority select element.
const prioritySelect = document.getElementById('priority');
// Get a list of all elements with the 'todo' class.
const allTodos = document.querySelectorAll('.todo');

console.log('form:', form);
console.log('todoPane:', todoPane);
console.log('titleInput:', titleInput);
console.log('prioritySelect:', prioritySelect);
Task 2
  1. Go to the codepen.
  2. Fill in the body of createElement() first.
  3. Now follow the instructions at the end and insert newElement into the DOM
const todoPane = document.getElementById('todo-pane');

function createElement(title) {
// Create the text node with the variable 'title'.
const newTextNode = document.createTextNode(title);
// Create a new list item element to contain the text node.
const newListItem = document.createElement('li');
// Add the text node to the list item element.
newListItem.appendChild(newTextNode);
// Return the new element.
return newListItem;
}

const newElement = createElement('This is the title');

// Insert newElement into the unordered list with id 'todo-pane'.
todoPane.appendChild(newElement);
todoPane.appendChild(newElement2);
Task 3
  1. Go to the codepen.
  2. Remove the list item elements using Element.remove().
const removeListItem = document.querySelector('.todo');
removeListItem.remove();
document.querySelector('.todo').remove();
Task 4
  1. Go to the codepen.
  2. Add a submit handler to the form.
const form = document.forms.todo;

Add a submit handler to the form that displays an alert.
Can you find different ways to trigger the alert?

const form = document.querySelector('form');

function sayHi(event) {
alert('Hi!');
}

form.addEventListener('submit', sayHi);
Task 5
  1. Go to the codepen.
  2. Add a submit listener to the form that prevents default.
  3. Confirm the form can’t be submitted.
  4. Add a click listener to the todo note that removes it.
Get the form by ID from the forms collection.
const form = document.forms.todo;

1. Add a submit listener to the form that prevents default.
2. Fill out the title and submit
3. It shouldn't submit and you shouldn't see 'Not Found'.
4. Add a click listener to the list item. When clicked it should remove the element from the DOM.

const form = document.getElementById('todo');

form.addEventListener('submit', function (event) {
event.preventDefault();
});

const removeItem = document.querySelector('li');

removeItem.addEventListener('click', function (event) {
const todoToRemove = event.currentTarget;
todoToRemove.remove();
})
Task 6
  1. Putting it all together
  2. Go to the codepen.
// Store the URL of an image for each priority level.
const priorityImages = {
low: 'https://cdn1.iconfinder.com/data/icons/prettyoffice8/256/Flag-green.png',
medium: 'https://cdn1.iconfinder.com/data/icons/prettyoffice8/256/Flag-yellow.png',
high: 'https://cdn1.iconfinder.com/data/icons/prettyoffice8/256/Flag-red.png',
};

// Get the form by ID from the forms collection.
const form = document.getElementById('todo');
// Get the todo pane (the 'ul' element) to insert todos into.
const todoPane = document.getElementById('todo-pane');
// Get the text input for the title. We'll read from this when creating the todo.
const titleInput = document.getElementById('title');
// Get the priority select element. We'll read from this when creating the todo.
const prioritySelect = document.getElementById('priority');
// Get a *live* list of all elements with the 'todo' class.
const allTodos = document.querySelectorAll('.todo');

// Add an event listener that will
// 1. Create a new todo. The details should come from the form.
// 2. Insert it into the DOM.
// 3. Clear the title input ready to create a new todo note.
// 4. Prevent the default behaviour (ie don't submit to a server).

function createTodo(title, priority) {
// Create the text node with the variable 'title'.
const newTextNode = document.createTextNode(title);
// Create a new list item element to contain the text node.
const newListItem = document.createElement('li');

// Optional extras:
// 1. Add an image for the priority. The URLs are stored in the priorityImages object.
const image = document.createElement('img');
image.src = priorityImages[priority];
newListItem.appendChild(image);

// Add the text node to the list item element.
newListItem.appendChild(newTextNode);

// The most recently created list item (only!) should have the 'just-created' class.
newListItem.classList.add('todo', 'just-created');

// Optional extras:
// 1. Add a click handler to the note that deletes it on click using Element.remove().
newListItem.addEventListener('click', function(event) {
const todoRemove = event.currentTarget;
todoRemove.remove();
})

// Return the new element.
return newListItem;
}
form.addEventListener('submit', function (event) {
event.preventDefault();
const newElement = createTodo(titleInput.value, prioritySelect.value);
todoPane.appendChild(newElement)
form.reset();
});

Intro to JS - Intro to the DOM - Practical Tasks

Posted by Jonathan on Feb 19 2024

Initial codepen/template codepen.io/andrushka/pen/rNdQmOd
We are going to be creating a page that showcases some of our favourite animals. The page must contain some filters that will show/ hide the animals based on which filters are clicked. For example if you have images of pandas, tigers, lions and giraffes, when the giraffe filter is clicked the other animals get hidden.
We will also have a text input that can be used to filter the images based on their descriptions. For example if you have an image called “tiger jumping” and an image called “lion jumping” then typing “jump” into the search box should hide the other posts and show just these 2.
We need both of these things to work together so if the word “jump” is searched and the lion filter is clicked, only the lion post will show

Task 1
  1. Go to codepen.io/andrushka/pen/rNdQmOd
  2. Pick 4 animals
  3. Go to pexels.com and get 4 pictures of each animal (16 total)
  4. Create a HTML page containing a search input, 4 buttons (one for each animal), 1 more button labelled “Show All”
  5. Give each button a class of “buttonFilter”
  6. Add 16 containers with the animal images randomly spread out. Add a class that represents the animal class=”tiger”
Solution

Task 2
  1. Add a second class to each container that is called “imageFilter”.
  2. Add an attribute to each button animal =”tiger” (Show all, animal =”all”)
  3. Add a variable const button = document.querySelectorAll(".buttonFilter");
  4. const images = document.querySelectorAll(".imageFilter");
Solution

Task 3
  1. Loop through each button in the button array.
  2. Add an event listener for each button that looks for a click event
  3. Grab the animal attribute with animal = this.getAttribute("animal");
Solution

Task 4
  1. Loop through each item in the images array
  2. If animal = all change all of the containers to display:block
  3. If animal = “tiger” then if the container contains the class tiger display:block otherwise display:none
Solution

Task 5
  1. Add a keyup event to the search box
  2. The text entered should be used to filter based on the image alt attribute (or use the src attribute if you have no alts)
  3. The selected filter button should also be taken into account
Solution

Task 6
  1. Add CSS classes that show which filter is currently selected by adding a border to the clickable element.
  2. Add some helper text above the images that says something like “showing animals that match the search “{searchString}” and the filter {filter}
Solution

GitHub repository: The-DOM-Practical-Tasks

Blog Post Ten
